Context:
Limberlost Place is a 10-storey mass-timber, net-zero building under construction at Queens Quay East and Dockside Drive in Toronto. It is expected to welcome students in January 2025. This will be the first institutional building of its kind in Ontario and is inspired by the Limberlose Forest and Wildlife Reserve near Huntsville, Ontario. The construction of the building will contribute to revisions of national and provincial building codes.

Canadian business leader and philanthropist Jack Cockwell donated $18 million to George Brown College for the Limberlost Place project in two instalments, in 2015 and 2021. This is one of the largest donations made to the college.

The Brookfield Sustainability Institute (BSI) will be based at Limberlost Place and is focused on aligning digital transformation and sustainability. The BSI Chair and CEO is Luigi Ferrara, Dean of George Brown’s Centre for Arts, Design, and Information Technology.

Limberlost Place will be home to the School of Architectural Technology and the School of Computer Technology. It will also host the college’s third permanent fitness centre and a new indigenous space focused on cultural events and programming. A child care space is planned for this landmark new building, in recognition of a $750,000 donation from Dr. Eric and Mrs. Sara Jackman and the Jackman Foundation.

Mary Jackman (1904-1994), a Toronto pioneer in early childhood education, founded the Bond Street Nursery, believed to be the first early child care agency in Toronto, which existed for over 80 years. The Jackman Foundation honors her vision with its support of an early childcare centre named Mary's Place.

Mary's Place is part of the community programming in a new building, Limberlost Place. Limberlost Place is years ahead of Toronto's 2030 goals for sustainable design and performance for new developments. It is built with made-in-Canada mass-timber components and features generous spaces focused on well-being, access to natural light and fresh air, green energy harnessing from the surrounding environment including Lake Ontario, a passive ventilation system with solar chimneys, and smart daylight sensors and dimming controls. Limberlost Place has won several awards since its project design was unveiled in 2018, including Architizer A+ Awards, Sustainable Unbuilt Non-Residential Project [Jury Winner] (2023), Royal Architectural Institute of Canada Awards, Research & Innovation in Architecture Award (2023), Rethinking the Future, Architecture Construction and Design Award, Institutional, Concept Category (2022), and Waterfront Toronto Design Review Panel Awards, Excellence in Design Innovation (2022).

The text mentions several awards won by Moriyama Teshima Architects and Acton Ostry Architects for their design of Limberlost Place at George Brown College. Here is a list of the awards mentioned:

1. Global Future Design Award, Education Category – Gold Winner (2022) from Architecture Press Release
2. WAF (World Architecture Festival), WAFX Award (2022) & Shortlisted for Future Projects – Education Category (2022)
3. Ontario Engineering Projects Award (OEPA), Award of Excellence (2021) and Willis Chapman Award – Best in Province (2021) from the Association of Consulting Engineering Companies
4. WAN (World Architecture News) Award, Future – Education Category (2019)
5. AZ (AZURE) Award, People’s Choice: Unbuilt Projects (2019) and Best in Concepts: Unbuilt Project (2019)
6. MIPIM/The Architectural Review, AR Future Projects Award, Sustainability Prize (2019)
7. ReThinking the Future Award, Architecture, Construction and Design Award, Institutional Concept Category (2018) and Certificate of First Award (2018)
8. Canadian Architect, Award of Excellence (2018)

The text also mentions that Moriyama Teshima Architects has received over 200 awards including six Governor-General's Medals for architecture. Additionally, Acton Ostry Architects designed the Brock Commons Tallwood House, an 18-storey student residence at the University of British Columbia.

The contact information for George Brown College includes a phone number (416-415-2000) and TTY number (1-877-515-5559), email address (ask.george@georgebrown.ca), and social media hub link. The website content is subject to change without notice.
